verses.text: He that loveth his son causeth him oft to feel the rod, That he may have joy of him in the end.
He that chastiseth his son shall have joy in him, And shall rejoice of him among \add his\add* acquaintance.
He that teacheth his son grieveth the enemy: And before \add his\add* friends he shall rejoice of him.
Though his father die, yet \add he is\add* as though he were not dead: For he hath left \add one\add* behind him \add that is\add* like himself.
While he lived, he saw and rejoiced in him: And when he died, he was not sorrowful.
He left behind him an avenger against \add his\add* enemies, And one that shall requite kindness to \add his\add* friends.
He that maketh too much of \add his\add* son shall bind up his wounds; And his bowels will be troubled at every cry.
A horse not broken becometh headstrong: And a child left to himself will be wilful.
Cocker \add thy\add* child, and he shall make thee afraid: Play with him, and he will bring thee to heaviness.
Laugh not with him, lest thou have sorrow with \add him\add*, And \add lest\add* thou gnash thy teeth in the end.
Give him no liberty in \add his\add* youth, And wink not at his follies.
Bow down his neck while \add he is\add* young, And beat him on the sides while he is a child, Lest he wax stubborn, and be disobedient unto thee, And \add so\add* bring sorrow to thine heart.
Chastise thy son, and hold him to labour, Lest his lewd behaviour be an offence unto thee.
Better \add is\add* the poor, \add being\add* sound and strong of constitution, Than a rich \add man\add* that is afflicted in his body.
Health and good state of body \add are\add* above all gold, And a strong body above infinite wealth.
There is no riches above a sound body, And no joy above the joy of the heart.
Death \add is\add* better than a bitter life Or continual sickness.
Delicates poured upon a mouth shut up \add Are as\add* messes of meat set upon a grave.
What good doth the offering unto an idol? For neither can it eat nor smell: So \add is\add* he that is persecuted of the Lord.
He seeth with \add his\add* eyes and groaneth, As an eunuch that embraceth a virgin and sigheth.
Give not over thy mind to heaviness, And afflict not thyself in thine own counsel.
The gladness of the heart \add is\add* the life of man, And the joyfulness of a man prolongeth his days.
Love thine own soul, And comfort thy heart, Remove sorrow far from thee: For sorrow hath killed many, And there is no profit therein.
Envy and wrath shorten the life, And carefulness bringeth age before the time.
A cheerful and good heart will have a care of his meat \add and\add* diet.
